comment.author: 57668330@N00
comment._content: This is the 1913 groundbreaking for the never-completed National American Indian Memorial: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_American_Indian_Memorial

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: Date is 22 February 1913 according to the Wikipedia article on the event. More on Rodman Wanamaker. The article on the memorial mentioned above mentions: Also in attendance were 32 or 33 American Indian chiefs, including Red Hawk and Two Moons. Red Hawk was a Sioux and Two Moons was a Cheyenne. It would probably be possible to identify some of the more prominent Native Americans in the photos. Red Hawk was very famous--a photo of him from 1907 is here, and a short Wikipedia article with photo of Two Moons. I have made some tentative identifications on the photo, but it is hard to say. There is a New York Times article from 23 February 1913 about this event. It is quite lengthy, with some biographical information on the participants, but there are no detailed captions for the photos.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
rockcreek and cotinis:

Thanks to both of you for the additional information about this photograph and the event it depicts.  It is difficult to make definitive identifications of all the individuals shown, but we can at the least add more details about the ceremony to this record.

comment.author: 16909288@N00
comment._content: The tall native third from right is Jack Redcloud, son of the famous Lakota chief who was known as Redcloud and who won a war with the United States in 1866--Redcloud's War, of course.  Redcloud, the father, was a great man, brave, wise, stubborn, and infamous in his youth for killing the tyrant Bull Bear.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: clickr100: Thank you for the identification of Jack Red Cloud! Other photographs in the Prints and Photographs Division's holdings, particularly this one by Edward Curtis, can certainly serve as additional proof of his identity. We will update the source data and reload the description to Flickr.

comment.author: 39611311@N06
comment._content: The Cheyenne Chief Two Moons stands second from left on this photo!!! First from left is Cheyenne Chief Wooden Leg. To the right from Rodman Wanamaker stands Crow Chief Plenty Coups, Crow Chief Medicine Crow, Crow man White Man Runs Him...

comment.author: 76028129@N00
comment._content: Wanamaker was adopted into the Crow Tribe by Chief Plenty Coups in late November of 1921.  Hairy Moccasin, White Man Runs Him and Curley, Crow scouts at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, were all in attendance at Wanamaker's adoption at Crow Agency and the Little Bighorn Battlefield.  Source Billings Gazette, November 27, 1921.  The fact that Two Moons and Wooden Leg, both who fought against Custer and the Crows, are in attendance, makes me think this was photographed at the Little Bighorn Battlefield.  It does not look like a sunny late June afternoon during a Custer re-enactment event, but you never know in Montana.
